body.head.byline: By CARA BUCKLEY; Daryl Khan and Timothy Williams contributed reporting.

abstract.p: Laura Sergio faces murder charges after her newborn baby is found in garbage bag on back porch of her home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; her sisters Andria and Cara are charged with improper disposal of human body and obstructing police investigation; police were called by hospital workers who surmised Sergio had given birth; photo (M)

block.p: A 25-year-old woman who went to a Brooklyn hospital on Friday night suffering from abdominal pain and excessive bleeding was arrested yesterday in the death of her newborn daughter, who was later found in a garbage bag on the back porch of the woman's family home, the police said.

The woman, Laura Sergio, was charged with murder last night, while her two sisters, Andria Sergio, 27, and Cara Sergio, 29, were charged, respectively, with improper disposal of a human body and obstructing the police investigation.

A 25-year-old woman who went to a Brooklyn hospital on Friday night suffering from abdominal pain and excessive bleeding was arrested yesterday in the death of her newborn daughter, who was later found in a garbage bag on the back porch of the woman's family home, the police said.

The woman, Laura Sergio, was charged with murder last night, while her two sisters, Andria Sergio, 27, and Cara Sergio, 29, were charged, respectively, with improper disposal of a human body and obstructing the police investigation.
About 9:45 p.m. on Friday, according to the police, an ambulance was called to the Tudor-style house of the women's parents, Dominick and Lena Sergio, on Colonial Road in Bay Ridge.
Laura Sergio had passed out on the bathroom floor, the police said, and was taken to Lutheran Medical Center, where hospital workers surmised that she had recently given birth.
When they asked Ms. Sergio where the baby was, she was evasive, the police said. The hospital called the police shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday, and officers went to the Sergio family's home.

The police said they found two garbage bags on the back porch. One was filled with bloodied rags and towels, and the other contained a baby girl, unresponsive and wrapped in a towel, the police said. The infant was also taken to Lutheran Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead.
Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner's office, said the baby had been carried to full term, was born alive, and died of asphyxiation and hypothermia.
The discovery dismayed neighbors, who said trouble was rare along their street. Many said they were unaware that Laura Sergio had been pregnant.
''You don't expect anybody, especially in this neighborhood, to do anything of that sort,'' said Christie Marrone, 20, who said she lived nearby and knew the Sergios.
Ms. Marrone said that the Sergios often held backyard barbecues, and that Lena Sergio was notoriously strict.
Another neighbor, Virginia Michaels, 51, said she sometimes heard Lena Sergio yelling at her daughters, though other neighbors insisted they had seen no signs of family conflict.
Ms. Michaels said that Mr. Sergio was a public school teacher and that his wife worked as a secretary at Long Island University.
